what_happened: A maintenance crew was preparing to remove a hydraulic actuator for seal replacement. The hydraulic supply and return lines were isolated the previous afternoon, and the system was drained using the standard bleed point. A zero ‑ pressure reading on the local gauge was confirmed before the job was left overnight. Early the next morning, the crew began unbolting the actuator housing. As they loosened the final bolts, the top plate lifted slightly and a short pulse of fluid escaped. The actuator then moved a few millimetres—indicating that pressure had re ‑ accumulated. Work was stopped immediately. Operations determined that a slow ‑ backflow leak through an aging check valve allowed trapped fluid to gradually refill an accumulator overnight, despite the isolation. This phenomenon— isolation drift —was not detected during the initial verification because the pressure rise was slow and occurred after the shift ended. The accumulator was fully depressurized, isolation points were replaced and retested, and the job resumed safely.
what_could_have_happened: Actuator housing or cover could have ejected under pressure Hydraulic spray could have resulted in eye or skin injuries Actuator displacement could have pinched or struck a worker A larger pressure surge could have compromised nearby piping or seals
why_did_it_happen: Isolation procedure lacked requirements for time ‑ based re-verification of hydraulic accumulators Aging check valve allowed slow replenishment of pressure despite upstream isolation Documentation did not clearly flag accumulators as stored ‑ energy devices needing independent bleed ‑ down
causal_factors: Work was left overnight without secondary or redundant verification in the morning Congested layout made it difficult to inspect small-bore hydraulic lines and check valves Team relied on a single gauge reading rather than checking multiple points Pressure rise occurred gradually, masking the drift until disassembly Shift turnover did not reinforce the possibility of overnight pressure regeneration
what_went_well: Mechanic recognized abnormal movement and stepped away immediately Crew halted the job and escalated rather than attempting field troubleshooting Operations quickly traced the backflow path and safely depressurized the accumulator Barricades and PPE minimized exposure risk from the small release The learning was captured promptly and shared across teams
lessons_to_prevent: Hydraulic systems with accumulators require multi ‑ point and time ‑ based pressure verification Check valves on hydraulic circuits must be regularly inspected for slow bypass leakage Isolation plans must explicitly identify and bleed all stored ‑ energy components Jobs paused overnight must include a next ‑ shift re ‑ verification before work resumes Gauges should not be the sole indicator of zero energy—use redundant methods

title: Cascading Pressure Release from Multiple Hydraulic Accumulators
what_happened: A maintenance team was performing a hydraulic oil flush on a header that feeds several large valve actuators. The isolation plan called for shutting off the main hydraulic supply, draining the header at a central low point, and locking out the pump. The gauge at the drain point read zero, and the team believed the system was safely depressurized. Over time, multiple small accumulators had been added at various actuators to improve stroking performance during upsets. These accumulators were located at different elevations and connected via check valves. They were not all identified in the isolation package. As the crew began removing a spool piece near one of the actuators, a short pulse of oil pushed the flange apart, followed by a second, larger surge a few seconds later. Each time, the mechanic quickly re ‑ tightened the bolts and stepped away. Investigation found that residual pressure from several accumulators was cascading into the open point in sequence as check valves cracked under gravity and header movement. Once Operations systematically bled each accumulator, the header remained at zero and the job was completed without injury.
what_could_have_happened: A larger combined release from multiple accumulators could have ejected the spool or bolts, striking workers. High ‑ pressure hydraulic spray could have caused serious eye or skin injuries. Sudden opening of the line could have led to loss of footing on an oil ‑ contaminated floor. Uncontrolled valve movement downstream could have upset process conditions.
why_did_it_happen: Isolation procedure did not require a complete inventory and bleed ‑ down of all accumulators connected to the header. Asset documentation and P&IDs were not updated to reflect additional accumulators installed over time. No formal risk assessment was carried out when accumulators were added, so cascading pressure pathways were not considered.
causal_factors: Accumulators were installed at different times by different project teams, leading to fragmented knowledge. Check valves and small ‑ bore lines were partially hidden by insulation and pipe racks, making them easy to overlook. The team relied on a single low ‑ point gauge, which did not reflect pressure trapped above local check valves. Time pressure during a turnaround encouraged reliance on prior isolation patterns instead of full re ‑ evaluation. Shift handover did not emphasize that additional accumulators had been noted in earlier inspections.
what_went_well: Mechanic reacted quickly to unexpected movement and immediately stopped work. The crew respected the stop ‑ work and did not attempt repeated loosening until the cause was understood. Operations supported a systematic bleed ‑ down, walking the line and depressurizing each accumulator safely. Barricades and PPE reduced the likelihood of direct impact or spray injuries. The event was reported and investigated promptly, enabling a structured review of hydraulic isolation practices.
lessons_to_prevent: Hydraulic isolation plans must identify and bleed every accumulator connected to the system, not just the main header. Single-point gauge readings are insufficient for complex hydraulic networks; multiple verification points are needed. Any retrofit or project work adding accumulators must be captured through Management of Change and documentation updates. Field walkdowns should trace small ‑ bore lines and check valves that can enable cascading pressure. Overnight or extended isolations should be followed by a fresh pressure check before breaking any flanges.

title: Blocked Bleed ‑ Path Failure Led to Unexpected Hydraulic Pressure Release
what_happened: A maintenance crew was preparing to remove a hydraulic cylinder from a large process valve for seal refurbishment. The hydraulic supply was isolated, and the team opened the primary bleed point used in the isolation procedure. The gauge reading dropped to zero, and the crew believed the system was depressurized. However, the bleed line—located at the bottom of the manifold—had become partially blocked by degraded seal material and debris. This blockage allowed a small amount of fluid to drain initially but prevented the trapped fluid in the actuator barrel from fully releasing. As the technician loosened the final bolts on the cylinder end cap, the accumulated pressure suddenly forced the cap to shift outward, accompanied by a short burst of hydraulic oil. Stop ‑ work was invoked immediately. Operations depressurized the actuator through an auxiliary bleed fitting, removed debris from the blocked line, and replaced the bleed assembly before work proceeded. No injuries occurred.
what_could_have_happened: End cap could have been propelled outward under pressure, striking a worker. Hydraulic spray could have caused burns, eye injuries, or skin injection. Line movement could have knocked nearby tools or equipment into workers. Larger structural movement could have compromised the adjacent valve body.
why_did_it_happen: Isolation procedure relied on a single bleed path with no redundancy. Bleed line internals were not part of routine inspection or preventive maintenance. System design lacked a secondary upstream bleed point for trapped energy verification.
causal_factors: Debris from aged internal seals accumulated inside the bleed line. Technicians depended solely on gauge readings without verifying flow at the bleed point. Congested equipment layout made it difficult to visually inspect bleed tubing. The crew assumed previous isolations on the same valve were representative of current conditions. Turnover between shifts did not highlight recent flow abnormalities noted during flushing.
what_went_well: Technician recognized abnormal movement and stepped back immediately. Stop ‑ work authority was used effectively. Operations rapidly located the true bleed point and safely released the trapped energy. PPE (gloves, eye protection) reduced exposure risk during the fluid release. The team reported the deviation promptly, enabling fast procedural review.
lessons_to_prevent: Use redundant bleed paths when isolating hydraulic systems that may contain trapped energy. Verify bleed functionality by confirming sustained flow, not just pressure drop. Include bleed lines and small ‑ bore tubing in preventive maintenance. Add secondary verification (e.g., crack fittings or upstream gauges) before disassembly. Inspect hydraulic systems for blockages after seal failures or component degradation. Include blocked bleed ‑ path hazards in training for hydraulic isolations.

title: Hydraulic–Pneumatic Migration Caused Unexpected Actuator Motion
setting: Gas Compression Area – Valve Actuation Systems
what_happened: A maintenance crew was assigned to replace a leaking hydraulic hose on a large process isolation valve. The valve was fitted with a hybrid actuation package: a hydraulic actuator for normal operation and a small pneumatic assist unit intended for emergency positioning during hydraulic system outages. Prior to starting work, Operations isolated the hydraulic power unit feeding the actuator, shut the local hydraulic block valves, and opened the designated bleed point. The pressure gauge on the hydraulic manifold fell to zero, and the permit was authorized. The pneumatic side was left connected because the valve was not expected to move while hydraulic pressure was removed. As the technician loosened the hydraulic hose connection at the actuator, the actuator rod unexpectedly moved a few millimetres and a small quantity of oil exited under pressure. The movement startled the worker but caused no contact. The crew stopped the job immediately and reported the deviation. Investigation found that the pneumatic assist circuit, still pressurized, was back ‑ feeding through an internal migration path into the hydraulic side via a shuttle valve, re ‑ pressurizing the hydraulic chamber despite the main hydraulic isolation. The valve was placed in a safe position, the pneumatic supply was isolated and vented, and both circuits were re ‑ verified before the hose replacement proceeded without further incident.
what_could_have_happened: A larger stroke of the actuator could have trapped a hand or arm between moving components. Hydraulic fittings could have failed under unexpected pressure, causing high ‑ pressure fluid injection or spray. Unintended valve movement could have altered process conditions upstream or downstream. If the line had been opened further, a more significant release of hydraulic fluid could have caused slip hazards or impacted nearby equipment.
why_did_it_happen: The actuation system design allowed internal migration between pneumatic and hydraulic circuits via a shuttle valve, but this interaction was not clearly documented. The isolation procedure considered hydraulic and pneumatic systems separately and did not require simultaneous isolation of both energy sources on dual ‑ mode actuators. Management of change for the addition of the pneumatic assist function did not fully assess or communicate the new energy paths created by the hybrid design.
causal_factors: The small ‑ bore pneumatic line and shuttle valve were partially obscured by insulation and other pipework, making the dual ‑ mode configuration easy to overlook during the field walkdown. The maintenance crew was familiar with single ‑ mode hydraulic actuators and assumed similar isolation steps were sufficient. Job planning time was limited due to a compressed outage window, reducing detailed review of the actuation schematic. Shift handover notes referenced “pneumatic backup” in general terms but did not specify its impact on isolation requirements.
what_went_well: The technician immediately recognized abnormal actuator movement and used stop ‑ work authority. The work party stayed clear of the primary pinch points, minimizing injury potential. Operations responded quickly, isolated and vented the pneumatic supply, and verified zero energy before work resumed. The event was reported promptly, triggering a structured review of hybrid actuation systems in the area.
lessons_to_prevent: Dual ‑ mode actuators must be treated as having multiple energy sources; all associated circuits (hydraulic and pneumatic) must be isolated and vented before work. Actuation schematics and field labelling must clearly show any internal migration paths or shuttle valves between energy media. Isolation procedures should explicitly require simultaneous lockout of all actuation feeds on hybrid equipment. Field walkdowns must include tracing all small ‑ bore lines to confirm how assist or backup circuits interact with the primary actuator. Shift handovers should highlight non ‑ standard actuation designs and any implications for isolation.

title: Hydraulic–Pneumatic Interaction Led to Unexpected Valve Stroke
setting: Utilities Area – Hybrid Pneumatic/Hydraulic Valve Actuation
what_happened: A maintenance crew was troubleshooting a process isolation valve equipped with a hybrid actuation system: a pneumatic actuator for normal operation and a hydraulic “boost” circuit used for fast closure during upsets. The task was to replace the pneumatic positioner and check linkage alignment. Operations isolated the pneumatic supply, vented the actuator, and confirmed the valve held position. The hydraulic pump was left in service to support other valves on the same header. During testing, the instrument technician commanded small pneumatic steps with the positioner air line disconnected to verify mechanical motion. When no movement was observed, the technician began adjusting the stem linkages. As bolts were loosened, the valve suddenly rotated several degrees. Subsequent investigation found that the hydraulic booster circuit shared an internal shuttle with the pneumatic chamber. A transient pressure change in the hydraulic header—caused by another valve stroking nearby—migrated through the shuttle and pressurized the “isolated” pneumatic chamber, resulting in a short uncontrolled valve stroke while the linkage was partially undone. The team stopped work immediately and no one was injured.
what_could_have_happened: The unexpected stroke could have trapped the mechanic’s hand or wrist in the linkage. A larger valve movement could have altered process conditions and upset downstream equipment. If the bolts had been further removed, the actuator could have shifted or separated, creating flying-component hazards. Hydraulic fittings might have failed, causing a high ‑ pressure fluid release.
why_did_it_happen: Hybrid actuator design allowed internal migration between pneumatic and hydraulic chambers, but this was not clearly documented. Isolation procedures treated pneumatic and hydraulic systems separately and did not require combined isolation for hybrid actuators. Management of change for the original hydraulic boost upgrade did not fully evaluate or communicate the new cross ‑ coupling risks.
causal_factors: Small ‑ bore hydraulic lines and the shuttle block were obscured by insulation and nearby pipework. Job planning focused on the positioner and air side; the hydraulic schematic was not reviewed. Multiple maintenance activities on the hydraulic header caused pressure transients that were not considered during SIMOPS planning. Technicians relied on previous experience with single ‑ mode pneumatic actuators and assumed similar behavior.
what_went_well: The mechanic reacted quickly to unexpected motion and used stop ‑ work authority. Body positioning kept hands mostly out of the pinch zone during adjustment. Operations responded promptly and isolated both pneumatic and hydraulic feeds before work resumed. The event was reported immediately, allowing quick learning and procedure updates.
lessons_to_prevent: Treat any hybrid actuator as having multiple coupled energy sources; isolate and vent them all before work. Ensure actuation schematics clearly show shuttle valves, boosters, and potential cross ‑ coupling paths. Include hybrid actuation reviews in SIMOPS planning where shared headers are in use. Use field walkdowns to trace all pneumatic and hydraulic lines, not just those on the main actuator body. Train maintenance and operations staff on the specific risks of pneumatic–hydraulic interaction.

title: Cross ‑ Header Interaction Failure Led to Unexpected Pressure Transfer
setting: Process Unit – Multi ‑ Header Utility / Process Network
what_happened: A maintenance crew was preparing to install a new flow element on a section of a utility header supplying instrument air. Operations isolated the instrument air header upstream and downstream, installed blinds, and verified zero pressure at the local drain. Work proceeded as planned. During flange separation, the team noticed a sudden rise in pressure at the break point—short bursts of air escaped, and the line shifted several millimetres. Stop ‑ work authority was immediately applied. A subsequent investigation revealed that a parallel process air header —running adjacent to the isolated header—had a small crossover line installed during a previous project. A malfunctioning check valve on this crossover allowed pressure to migrate from the active header into the isolated header. This cross ‑ header interaction was not shown on the simplified isolation drawing and had not been considered during the isolation planning. The header was re ‑ isolated at a more remote boundary, fully depressurized, and the job resumed safely.
what_could_have_happened: A higher ‑ pressure surge could have caused uncontrolled flange separation and expelled bolts or gaskets. Air movement could have propelled the spool into nearby workers. If the header had contained process gas rather than air, an exposure or flammability risk may have developed. Escalation into a full loss ‑ of ‑ containment event requiring area evacuation.
why_did_it_happen: Isolation planning did not identify interactions between parallel headers sharing legacy crossover connections. Drawings and isometric packages were outdated and did not capture the crossover or check valve arrangement. No formal cross ‑ header review step existed in the isolation procedure for multi ‑ header networks.
causal_factors: Congested pipe rack concealed the crossover line from ground ‑ level visibility. The check valve on the crossover was degraded and leaked under normal operating pressure. Time pressure during maintenance limited the depth of the initial walkdown. Incomplete shift handover failed to note past issues observed on the adjacent process air header. Relying solely on local pressure readings missed the drift from the parallel header.
what_went_well: Mechanic recognized abnormal pressure and immediately backed out of the break area. Team used stop ‑ work authority promptly, preventing further separation. Operations responded quickly to locate the cross ‑ header backflow path. Barricades limited non ‑ essential personnel exposure. Incident was reported early, enabling rapid learning and documentation updates.
lessons_to_prevent: Multi ‑ header systems require full interaction mapping, not just single ‑ header isolation logic. Isolation reviews must include crossover valves, tie ‑ ins, and check valves at all elevations. Pressure verification must be performed at multiple points and not rely on a single drain. MOC updates must ensure new cross ‑ connections are added to isolation templates and drawings. Cross ‑ header interactions must be explicitly addressed in SIMOPS meetings when concurrent work is occurring.

title: Multi ‑ Header Feed Mis ‑ Identification During Isolation
setting: Utilities – Multi ‑ Header Cooling Water System
what_happened: A maintenance team was assigned to replace a corroded section of piping on a cooling ‑ water header feeding several heat exchangers. The system had been upgraded over time and was now supplied by two separate feed headers (north and south), each capable of supplying the same distribution header via automated control valves. The isolation plan focused on closing the control valve from the north feed header and draining the distribution header at a low point. The pressure gauge at the drain read zero, and the job was cleared to proceed. The south feed header, which also had a connection into the same distribution header, was assumed to be isolated by its normal operating valve position and was not specifically included in the isolation list. When the crew loosened flange bolts at the repair location, they experienced a short burst of water and a brief line movement. Stop ‑ work was immediately applied. Operations traced the issue and found that a small pressure increase on the south header had opened its control valve slightly, re ‑ pressurizing the distribution header. The system was then correctly isolated at both feed headers, fully drained, and the repair was completed without injury.
what_could_have_happened: A higher pressure surge could have caused complete flange separation and pipe whip. Water and debris could have struck workers, resulting in impact or eye injuries. If the system had carried treated or chemically dosed water, a localized chemical exposure could have occurred. A larger loss of containment could have flooded the area, affecting access/egress and nearby equipment.
why_did_it_happen: Isolation planning did not fully account for multiple feed headers supplying the same distribution line. The system design and documentation did not clearly highlight dual feeds and their control logic as a specific isolation risk. Management of change for previous header tie ‑ ins did not update standard isolation templates or include a cross ‑ header risk review.
causal_factors: The south header was assumed to be “out of service” based on normal operating practice, not verified as part of the isolation. P&IDs and isometrics were complex and did not visually emphasize the dual ‑ feed arrangement. Time pressure during a busy outage reduced the depth of the field walkdown. Limited cross ‑ team discussion between Operations and Maintenance about how the automatic control valves on each header behaved when pressure changed.
what_went_well: The mechanic recognized abnormal water release and immediately invoked stop ‑ work. The crew stepped clear of the flange opening, preventing contact injuries. Operations quickly identified the second feed header and re ‑ established safe isolation. Area barricades limited the number of people in the vicinity when the deviation occurred. The incident was promptly reported, allowing lessons to be shared with other units using multi ‑ feed headers.
lessons_to_prevent: Always identify all potential feed sources into a header (including backup and standby lines) during isolation planning. Do not rely on “normal operating position” of feed valves—explicit isolation and verification are required. Isolation drawings should visually emphasize multi ‑ header connections and interlocks. Field walkdowns must confirm valve positions on every header feeding a common distribution line. SIMOPS / pre ‑ job meetings should include a specific review of cross ‑ header interactions when multiple feeds exist.

title: Tie ‑ In Isolation Drift Led to Unexpected Pressure Return
setting: Process Unit – Mixed Utility/Process Header Tie ‑ In
what_happened: A maintenance crew was preparing to install a new spool on a section of piping connected to a mixed ‑ service header. Operations isolated the main feed valve and drained the section through its designated low ‑ point drain. Pressure at the gauge dropped to zero, and the area was released for work. Unbeknownst to the team, the header had a secondary tie ‑ in line supplying a downstream piece of equipment that had been temporarily bypassed during earlier modifications. Its isolation valve was known to “creep” due to aging seals. Overnight, this valve slowly passed, causing upstream pressure to drift back into the “isolated” section. When the crew loosened the first flange bolts the next morning, a short, sharp release of fluid occurred, and the flange shifted slightly. Stop ‑ work authority was used immediately. Operations traced the issue to the tie ‑ in valve, fully depressurized the system, and replaced the failing isolation component before work resumed.
what_could_have_happened: A larger pressure surge could have caused full flange separation and projectiles. Workers could have been struck by fluid or the moving flange. Unexpected line movement could have unbalanced workers near elevated platforms. Loss of containment could have led to ignition risk depending on product.
why_did_it_happen: Isolation procedure did not require specific verification of all tie ‑ in valves feeding the work section. The bypassed system created an undocumented secondary pressure path into the isolated header. Preventive maintenance program did not adequately track valve degradation or leak ‑ through risk.
causal_factors: Physical congestion made it difficult to see the small tie ‑ in valve during the walkdown. The isolation plan relied solely on the primary block valve and a single pressure check. Shift handover did not highlight the bypassed system or valve creep history. Work start occurred after a long idle period, allowing isolation drift to accumulate. Time pressure during a busy outage reduced depth of field verification.
what_went_well: The mechanic stopped work immediately after noticing abnormal release. Crew maintained safe body positioning and avoided line ‑ of ‑ fire zones. Operations promptly identified and secured the failing tie ‑ in valve. Area barricades minimized personnel exposure. Incident was reported without delay, enabling fast learning distribution.
lessons_to_prevent: Tie ‑ in and bypass lines must be explicitly identified and verified during isolation planning. Systems left idle overnight require re ‑ verification of pressure before line breaks. Aging valves or known creep ‑ risk components must be flagged in job packages. Multi ‑ point pressure checks improve confidence in isolation effectiveness. MOC processes must update drawings and isolation templates whenever tie ‑ ins or bypasses are introduced.

title: Legacy ‑ Line Re ‑ Pressurization Caused Unexpected Pressure Return During Line Break
setting: Process Unit – Legacy Piping Network with Historical Tie ‑ Ins
what_happened: A maintenance team was preparing to perform a planned line break on a process drain header scheduled for partial replacement. Operations isolated the main feed valves, drained the section, confirmed zero pressure on the local gauge, and cleared the area for work. During flange loosening the next morning, the mechanic detected a slight hiss and minor flange movement as residual pressure escaped. Stop ‑ work authority was used immediately. Investigation revealed that a legacy line, abandoned years earlier but still physically connected behind insulation, had slowly re ‑ pressurized the isolated section. A degraded valve on the legacy line had allowed pressure from an adjacent active system to migrate through the old piping, re ‑ charging the isolated section overnight. Because the legacy line was not documented in current isolation drawings, it was not included in the isolation plan. Operations fully depressurized the legacy line, updated the boundary, and the work resumed safely.
what_could_have_happened: Full flange ejection could have resulted in serious injury from flying components. Pressurized fluid release could have struck workers or contaminated the work area. A larger re ‑ pressurization could have triggered loss of containment and a unit shutdown. Legacy ‑ line failure under pressure could have caused additional leaks elsewhere in the unit.
why_did_it_happen: Legacy piping was not removed, capped, or documented after historical system changes. Isolation documentation lacked a requirement to identify and verify inactive or abandoned lines connected to active systems. Management of change did not ensure that older line tie ‑ ins were captured in updated P&IDs and isolation templates.
causal_factors: Insulation and structural congestion concealed the legacy line and its isolation valve. Team relied heavily on existing drawings, unaware they were outdated regarding old tie ‑ ins. Night ‑ shift handover did not include re ‑ verification of pressure after equipment isolation. Aging legacy valve exhibited leak ‑ through not detectable from the main header gauge. Time pressure during outage limited the depth of the field walkdown.
what_went_well: Mechanic recognized abnormal pressure early and retightened the flange. Stop ‑ work authority was exercised promptly and effectively. Operations quickly traced the pressure source and established a safe isolation boundary. Barricades limited personnel exposure to the area during the deviation. Incident was reported immediately, enabling rapid procedural improvements.
lessons_to_prevent: All legacy lines must be identified, assessed, and either removed, capped, or formally documented in isolation plans. Isolation packages must include verification of all physical connections, not only those shown on drawings. Systems left isolated overnight require morning-of re-verification of pressure. Outdated P&IDs and tie ‑ in drawings must be updated before major isolations are planned. Leak ‑ through potential must be considered on older valves, especially those serving inactive lines.

title: Mis ‑ Mapped Tie ‑ In Boundary Led to Incorrect Isolation
setting: Process Unit – Mixed Service Tie ‑ In Network
what_happened: A maintenance crew was scheduled to cut into a utility/process tie ‑ in line to install a new measurement spool. Isolation planning referenced a simplified network drawing showing a single upstream boundary valve feeding the tie ‑ in. Operations isolated the identified valve, drained the section, and confirmed zero pressure on the local gauge. During flange separation, the mechanic noticed slight unexpected movement and a brief mist of fluid. Stop ‑ work authority was invoked immediately. Investigation showed that the tie ‑ in was mapped incorrectly in the isolation drawing. A second, older branch—added during a historical upgrade—fed into the same tie ‑ in from a different direction. Its isolation valve, located high on a pipe rack and partially hidden behind insulation, was not included in the isolation boundary. With the main line drained, backpressure from the hidden branch drifted into the “isolated” section, causing the partial re ‑ pressurization detected during the flange break. The line was fully re ‑ isolated at both points, depressurized, and work resumed safely.
what_could_have_happened: Full flange separation causing projectiles or impact injuries. Larger pressure release leading to spray exposure. If the line had contained hazardous service, the release could have triggered inhalation or ignition risks. Potential escalation into an unplanned unit shutdown.
why_did_it_happen: Network mapping did not accurately reflect all tie ‑ in routes and historical modifications. Isolation procedures did not require validation of secondary or legacy feed paths to the tie ‑ in. Documentation updates were inconsistent following multiple system changes over the years.
causal_factors: Overhead branch valve was obscured by insulation and structural members. Team relied solely on simplified isolation drawings rather than full P&ID review. Limited time for walkdown due to compressed outage schedule. Shift turnover did not highlight unusual system routing or historical bypasses. One ‑ point pressure verification missed drift from the unseen tie ‑ in.
what_went_well: Mechanic recognized abnormal release immediately and stopped work. Crew maintained good body positioning, avoiding direct line of fire. Operations responded quickly, traced the secondary path, and established a correct boundary. Barricades kept non ‑ essential personnel clear. Prompt reporting enabled rapid updates to isolation documentation.
lessons_to_prevent: All tie ‑ ins—including legacy and bypass lines—must be validated during boundary planning. Isolation plans must include multi ‑ source verification, not just primary feed checks. Field walkdowns should include elevated and congested areas where hidden valves may be located. Documentation must be updated whenever tie ‑ in routes change due to MOC or project work. Use redundant pressure checks to confirm true isolation.

title: TEST INCIDENT - Flange Leak
what_happened: During maintenance a small leak was detected on flange F-101.
what_could_have_happened: Potential spray exposure.
why_did_it_happen: Gasket failure due to age.
causal_factors: Inadequate PM schedule.
what_went_well: PPE was worn, leak was contained quickly.
lessons_to_prevent: Update PM schedule for gaskets.
